name: hc_cruise_ship_gdc_oversized
description: [HC] Cruise ship 2600 mÂ³/h + GDC 600x600 (2000) â†’ undersized
query: Cruise ship exhaust. 2600 mÂ³/h. GDC-600x600 in RF.

turns.content: Cruise ship exhaust. 2600 mÂ³/h. GDC-600x600 in RF.

For the cruise ship exhaust application, you've specified a GDC-600x600 filter housing with RF (stainless steel) material. The system is exposed to Outdoor Condensation, High Humidity, and Salt Spray.Unfortunately, this configuration is blocked. The GDC housing is not rated for marine environments due to its bolted construction, which doesn't meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for marine applications. Additionally, the housing has a C2 corrosion class, which is insufficient for the salt spray environment, as it accelerates corrosion of the zinc components.The requested airflow of 2600 mÂ³/h also exceeds the maximum capacity of 2000 mÂ³/h for a single 600x600 module. To handle the required airflow, we need to use a larger housing size.Currently, no standard catalog product satisfies all requirements simultaneously. A solution would need to be rated for marine environments (ENV_MARINE) and handle the specified airflow. I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.To proceed with the configuration of the protector stage, I need to know the filter depth for the GDP filter.To finalize the configuration, I also need to know the minimum expected ambient temperature and typical relative humidity at the installation site to assess the risk of condensation.

gemini.explanation: The system correctly identifies multiple critical issues with the user's request. It accurately flags that the requested airflow (2600 mÂ³/h) exceeds the maximum capacity for the specified GDC 600x600 unit (2000 mÂ³/h) and correctly identifies that the GDC product family is rated for indoor use only, making it unsuitable for a marine environment. The inclusion of a query regarding a 'protector stage' (GDP) demonstrates advanced engineering logic, anticipating the need for pre-filtration to protect the carbon media in an exhaust application.

dimension_explanations.correctness: Verified GDC 600x600 recommended airflow is 2000 mÂ³/h (PDF p.14), confirming 2600 mÂ³/h is excessive; verified GDC is specified 'FÃ¶r inomhusbruk' (Indoor use) (PDF p.14).
dimension_explanations.completeness: The response addresses the airflow, environment, and material constraints, and proactively initiates the configuration of a necessary pre-filter stage.
dimension_explanations.safety: Correctly blocks the use of an indoor-rated housing in a marine environment and prevents an airflow overload configuration.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional and consultative, appropriately directing the user to custom engineering for a complex non-standard requirement.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Demonstrates sound HVAC logic by inferring the need for pre-filtration (GDP) for a carbon filter application and explaining why the construction type is unsuitable for marine use.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Strictly adheres to the 'Indoor use' and airflow capacity constraints defined in the catalog.

strengths: Accurate verification of airflow capacity limits against catalog data
Correct application of environmental constraints (Indoor vs. Marine)
Proactive engineering logic regarding pre-filtration for carbon applications

openai.explanation: The system correctly flags that a single GDC 600x600 is undersized for 2600 mÂ³/h per the catalog, but it makes several unsupported/incorrect claims about marine blocking, leakage/hygiene requirements, and corrosion class for the GDC family. It also asks for irrelevant clarifications (GDP filter depth) given the user asked for a GDC carbon/patron housing.

dimension_explanations.correctness: It is correct that GDC 600x600 has recommended flow 2000 mÂ³/h (PDF GDC table), but the claim that GDC is C2-only and not available/appropriate in RF plus the stated marine/leakage/hygiene blocking rationale is not supported by the provided catalog text and is partly incorrect engineering framing.
dimension_explanations.completeness: It addresses sizing vs airflow and flags environmental concerns, but does not propose a viable standard alternative from the shown range (e.g., larger GDC size or parallel housings) and introduces unrelated GDP questions.
dimension_explanations.safety: Conservatively warning about salt spray/high humidity and corrosion risk is appropriate for cruise-ship exhaust, and blocking a potentially unsuitable configuration is safer than approving it without verification.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional and consultative, with clear statements and a reasonable escalation path to technical support.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: The airflow capacity reasoning is clear, but the environment/leakage/hygiene argument is a logical jump without tying to catalog-rated constraints, and the follow-up questions are not aligned to the selected product family.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: It violates catalog constraints by asserting GDC is not rated/available for marine and is C2-only despite the catalog indicating multiple material options (including RF) for GDC; it also fails to apply the obvious catalog-compliant sizing workaround (larger size or multiple housings).

strengths: Correctly checks airflow against the moduleâ€™s recommended capacity and identifies undersizing.
Appropriately highlights corrosion/salt-spray risk for marine applications and suggests escalation when uncertain.
weaknesses: Invents/overstates hard constraints (marine/hygiene/leakage class) not evidenced in the provided PDF and misstates corrosion class applicability for the requested RF material.
Asks irrelevant clarifications about GDP filter depth and ambient conditions instead of focusing on GDC sizing/material/installation arrangement.
pdf_citations: GDC 600x600: Rek. flÃ¶de = 2000 mÂ³/h, antal patroner = 16 (GDC MÃ…TT table, page showing 'GDC PATRONFILTERSKÃ…P').
Material page: RF (EN 1.4301) is listed as korrosivitetsklass C5, and ZM310 is listed as C5 (Material section page).

anthropic.explanation: The system correctly identifies the airflow mismatch (GDC 600x600 = 2000 mÂ³/h recommended, vs. 2600 mÂ³/h requested) and raises valid concerns about marine environment corrosion. However, it incorrectly states GDC has a C2 corrosion class when the PDF shows GDC is available in RF (stainless steel, C5), and the blocking logic is overly aggressive since the catalog explicitly lists RF as a material option for GDC. The response also becomes confused at the end, mentioning GDP filter depth and condensation questions that seem disconnected from the main recommendation.

dimension_explanations.correctness: GDC 600x600 recommended flow is 2000 mÂ³/h per PDF p.14, which the system correctly identifies as insufficient for 2600 mÂ³/h. However, the system claims GDC has C2 corrosion class â€” while the standard FZ version is C2, the user requested RF (stainless steel) which is rated C5 per PDF p.4, making the corrosion claim misleading.
dimension_explanations.completeness: The system identifies the airflow shortfall and marine concerns but fails to suggest a larger GDC size (e.g., GDC 900x600 at 3000 mÂ³/h) in RF material, which would address both issues; the trailing questions about GDP filter depth and humidity are confusing and disconnected.
dimension_explanations.safety: The system appropriately flags marine environment risks including salt spray corrosion and the need for higher corrosion class materials, which is sound engineering reasoning for a cruise ship application.
dimension_explanations.tone: The response mixes professional technical language with system-internal labels (ENV_MARINE) and becomes somewhat disjointed toward the end with unrelated clarification questions about GDP and condensation.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: The cause-effect chain for marine corrosion is sound, but the logic becomes contradictory â€” blocking RF material for corrosion reasons when RF is C5-rated, and the trailing GDP/condensation questions suggest confused reasoning flow.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: The system overly blocks the configuration by not recognizing that RF (C5) is a valid material option for GDC per the catalog, and fails to suggest the straightforward solution of upsizing to GDC 900x600-RF which would meet both airflow and corrosion requirements.

strengths: Correctly identifies that GDC 600x600 at 2000 mÂ³/h is insufficient for the 2600 mÂ³/h requirement
Appropriately raises marine environment concerns including salt spray and corrosion for a cruise ship application
weaknesses: Incorrectly blocks RF (stainless steel, C5) material for GDC when the PDF explicitly lists RF as an available material option â€” the C2 claim applies only to the standard FZ version
Fails to suggest the obvious solution of GDC 900x600 in RF (3000 mÂ³/h capacity, C5 corrosion rating) and instead declares no standard product exists, which is incorrect
Trailing questions about GDP filter depth and ambient temperature are confusing and disconnected from the main query

content_segments.text: For the cruise ship exhaust application, you've specified a GDC-600x600 filter housing with RF (stainless steel) material. The system is exposed to Outdoor Condensation, High Humidity, and Salt Spray.

Unfortunately, this configuration is blocked. The GDC housing is not rated for marine environments due to its bolted construction, which doesn't meet the leakage class and hygiene requirements for marine applications. Additionally, the housing has a C2 corrosion class, which is insufficient for the salt spray environment, as it accelerates corrosion of the zinc components.
The requested airflow of 2600 mÂ³/h also exceeds the maximum capacity of 2000 mÂ³/h for a single 600x600 module. To handle the required airflow, we need to use a larger housing size.

Currently, no standard catalog product satisfies all requirements simultaneously. A solution would need to be rated for marine environments (ENV_MARINE) and handle the specified airflow. I recommend contacting our Custom Engineering or Technical Support team with these specific technical requirements.
To proceed with the configuration of the protector stage, I need to know the filter depth for the GDP filter.
To finalize the configuration, I also need to know the minimum expected ambient temperature and typical relative humidity at the installation site to assess the risk of condensation.
